<s>7<\s>10 
which points are never seen in <s>the<\s> Bos, Bubalus or Bison 
The share which the mastoids take in the formation of 
the occiput is much smaller than in any of those three 
animals and hence its greater heighth in proportion to its 
width. In <u>Bubalus Caffir<\u> the width reaches a maximum. 
The occipital crest is much more strongly marked - in 
Ovibos, Capra and Ovis than in any of the three animals 
so frequently quoted. 
Coronal surface. We have now to discuss the most important 
portion of the skull, the coronal surface, which in the old 
male is almost concealed by the large spongy bases of the 
horncores. In the young animal in common with all the 
cavicorn ruminants, the Gnu and Giraffe excepted, they are 
supported by the frontal, while in the old male they extend 
far back over the Parietals and project<s>s<\s> over the occipital 
surface <s>see plate ii<\s>. In the Giraffe the horncore is situated on the parieto-
frontal suture, in the old male Gnu it extends over the suture 
as in Ovibos. Each is separated from its fellow by a diastema 
in the median line varying in width according to sex and 
age, the diastema being smallest in the old male. Each 
is raised above the coronal surface in the adult male at 
least eight inches, thence is passes horizontally outwards 
decreasing in size as far as a line passing in front of 
the orbit, where it turns suddenly downwards at a right-
angle and ends in a stout obtuse point<s>s<\s> that extends further 
down than the tips of the Paramastoid process <s>see Pl ii<\s>. In the 
female the horncores are much smaller and more cylindrical
